data.title: Right to Report and Get Police Action on Cybercrime
data.right_summary: You can file FIR for online fraud, hacking, or cyber attacks. Police must act on cyber complaints.
data.real_case: Cybercrime Victim v. Police, Mumbai Cyber Crime Cell, 2023
data.case_summary: Person defrauded of ₹5 lakh online; police initially ignored. After complaint to commissioner, arrested culprit.

law_links.summary: Cyber crime penalties; hacking, fraud, unauthorized access.
law_links.full_text: Unauthorized access to computer system is criminal offense; compensation available.

law_links.summary: Criminal provisions for hacking, viruses, spoofing, cyber fraud.
law_links.full_text: Criminal penalties including imprisonment up to 3 years for cyber crimes.

law_links.summary: Cheating and fraud; applies to online fraud.
law_links.full_text: Online fraud is cheating under IPC; prosecution possible.

user_actions: Document the cyber crime: screenshots, URLs, transaction details
Report immediately to cyber crime cell or local police
File detailed FIR with all evidence attached
Contact bank/payment provider for chargeback if financial
Request cyber crime cell to trace money transfer
File complaint with cybercrime helpline (if available in state)
File complaint with consumer commission if fraud
Pursue case for criminal conviction and civil compensation

escalation.time_limit: FIR immediately; prosecution within 3 years; compensation claim within 2 years

stages.action: File FIR with cyber cell immediately

state_variations.Maharashtra: Mumbai Cyber Crime Cell very active; high conviction rate
state_variations.Delhi: Delhi Cyber Crime Cell responsive; online reporting available

consequences_if_violated: Criminal prosecution of cyber criminal (3 years imprisonment possible)
Compensation to victim from criminal fund
Money recovery and reversal if possible
Consumer commission compensation for fraud
Criminal record on offender
data.cyber_crime_types: Online fraud, hacking, phishing, ransomware, identity theft, cyber stalking, defamation
data.prevention_tips: Don't share OTP/passwords, verify URLs before login, use strong passwords, enable 2FA, use VPN

data.title: Right Against Online Harassment
data.right_summary: Cyber bullying, online abuse, defamation, and threats are crimes. You can file FIR and get protection.
data.real_case: Online Abuse Victim v. Harasser, Delhi Cyber Police, 2023
data.case_summary: Person received threatening messages, abusive posts on social media. Harasser traced and prosecuted.

law_links.summary: Sending obscene messages, threatening messages online.
law_links.full_text: Sending offensive messages through internet is criminal offense.

law_links.summary: Cyber stalking and online harassment of women.
law_links.full_text: Following woman online with intent to know/insult is criminal.

law_links.summary: Defamation includes online defamation.
law_links.full_text: Posting false/defamatory content online is criminal offense.

user_actions: Screenshot/save all abusive messages or posts (URL, time, date)
Do not respond to harasser; do not engage
Block harasser on all social media platforms
Report post/account to social media platform
File FIR with cyber crime cell with screenshots
Apply for online harassment restraining order
File case in family court if harassment by spouse/relative
Seek compensation for emotional trauma

escalation.lawyer_needed: Yes, if escalated to criminal prosecution

stages.action: Block and report on social media

state_variations.Maharashtra: Strong cyber harassment laws; quick police action
state_variations.Delhi: Cyber Cell responsive to harassment complaints; fast investigation

consequences_if_violated: Criminal prosecution of harasser (imprisonment up to 3 years)
Online harassment restraining order issued
Account suspension/deletion on social media
Compensation for emotional harm
Civil defamation suit possible
data.reporting_options: Cyber Cell, Social Media Platform, Women's Cell, Family Court (if domestic)

data.title: Right to Maintenance and Alimony
data.right_summary: After separation/divorce, you can claim maintenance from spouse. Amount based on income and needs.
data.real_case: Wife v. Husband, Maharashtra Family Court, 2023
data.case_summary: Wife earned ₹20,000/month; husband ₹2,00,000. Court ordered husband to pay ₹50,000/month maintenance.

law_links.summary: Right to maintenance from spouse for wife, children, parents.
law_links.full_text: Person unable to maintain self can claim maintenance from spouse/parents.

law_links.summary: Maintenance during and after marriage.
law_links.full_text: Court can order either spouse to pay maintenance based on income.

law_links.summary: Maintenance rights as per personal law.
law_links.full_text: Each community has maintenance provisions in respective laws.

user_actions: Determine your actual needs: living expenses, children education, health
Gather spouse's income documents: salary, business accounts, tax returns
Calculate reasonable maintenance amount (typically 25-50% of spouse income)
File maintenance petition in magistrate/family court
Present evidence of expenses and spouse's income
Provide proof of child custody if applicable
Claim arrears of maintenance if already due
Get regular review of maintenance as circumstances change

escalation.time_limit: Maintenance can be claimed anytime during marriage or after separation

state_variations.Maharashtra: Maintenance typically 25-50% spouse income; indexed annually
state_variations.Delhi: Family courts liberal in granting maintenance
state_variations.Tamil_Nadu: Maintenance awarded considering cost of living

consequences_if_violated: Regular maintenance payment ordered by court
Arrears of maintenance with interest
Contempt of court if maintenance not paid
Employer can be directed to deduct from salary
Compensation for delay and hardship
data.maintenance_factors: Income of both spouses, living standard maintained, children needs, health conditions, age, earning capacity

data.title: Right to Divorce
data.right_summary: You can file for divorce if marriage has broken down. Both parties have equal rights to dissolve marriage.
data.real_case: Spouse v. Spouse, Delhi Family Court, 2023
data.case_summary: Mutual divorce filed and completed in 6 months with custody and maintenance agreed. Court granted decree.

law_links.summary: Divorce grounds and procedure for Hindu marriages.
law_links.full_text: Divorce can be obtained on grounds of cruelty, desertion, etc.

law_links.summary: Divorce provisions for Christian marriages.
law_links.full_text: Christian marriages can be dissolved on specified grounds.

law_links.summary: Divorce for marriages registered under SMA; mutual or contested.
law_links.full_text: Divorce procedure for marriages outside community laws.

user_actions: Attempt marriage counseling if desired (optional)
Gather marriage certificate and identity documents
If mutual consent: settle maintenance, custody, property division
If contested: document cruelty/desertion/other grounds
File divorce petition in family court with jurisdiction
For mutual: both file joint petition (faster process)
Get provisional custody and maintenance orders
Obtain final decree after completion of process

escalation.time_limit: Mutual divorce: 6 months minimum; contested: 1-3 years

state_variations.Maharashtra: Family courts professional; mutual divorce processed quickly
state_variations.Delhi: Liberal divorce laws; quick dispute resolution
state_variations.All_India: Respective marriage laws apply based on religion

consequences_if_violated: Divorce decree granted after court proceedings
Custody of children determined (best interest principle)
Maintenance and alimony ordered
Property division as per marital law
Freedom to remarry after decree becomes final
data.divorce_types: Mutual consent (faster, 6 months), Contested (cruelty, desertion, adultery, etc.)
data.custody_principle: Best interest of child; age/gender/ties to parent considered

data.title: Right to Compensation After Accident
data.right_summary: Accident victims have right to claim compensation from vehicle owner/driver's insurance or liable party.
data.real_case: Accident Victim v. Insurance, Mumbai District Court, 2023
data.case_summary: Person injured in car accident; liable driver insured. Court awarded ₹5 lakh compensation + medical bills.

law_links.summary: Compensation to victims of vehicle accidents.
law_links.full_text: Hit and run or accident compensation recoverable from insurer or vehicle owner.

law_links.summary: Compulsory insurance for all vehicles.
law_links.full_text: Every vehicle owner must have valid third-party insurance.

law_links.summary: Consumer claims against insurers for non-payment.
law_links.full_text: Insurance claim rejection can be challenged in consumer court.

user_actions: Seek immediate medical treatment if injured
Report accident to police and get FIR/report copy
Collect vehicle registration numbers of all parties
Take photos of accident scene and vehicle damage
Get witness contact information
Obtain medical reports and bills
File claim with insurance company within time limit
If rejected, file consumer complaint or file suit in motor accident tribunal

escalation.time_limit: Insurance claim within 30 days of accident; suit within 2 years

state_variations.Delhi: Quick compensation settlements; consumer court access

consequences_if_violated: Insurance company must pay compensation
Vehicle owner liable if insurance invalid/expired
Compensation for injury, loss of income, medical expenses
Loss of limb or disability: higher compensation (₹5-50 lakh)
Death compensation: ₹10-20 lakh typically
data.compensation_heads: Medical expenses, disability, loss of income, pain and suffering, vehicle damage, rehabilitation

data.title: Right Against Wrong Traffic Challan
data.right_summary: Traffic police can't fine you without reason. Wrong challans can be challenged in traffic court.
data.real_case: Driver v. Traffic Police, Bangalore High Court, 2023
data.case_summary: Driver fined ₹5,000 for 'over-speeding' at 30 km/h. Radar wasn't calibrated. Court cancelled challan.

law_links.summary: Traffic rules and penalties for violation.
law_links.full_text: Traffic violations can be fined; but fine must be justified.

law_links.summary: Appeal against traffic challan in traffic court.
law_links.full_text: Driver can appeal traffic fine in prescribed traffic court.

law_links.summary: Summary trial for traffic offenses.
law_links.full_text: Traffic cases decided quickly in summary trial procedure.

user_actions: Check challan validity: police signature, date, vehicle details
Verify offense: was it actually committed?
Collect photos/video if violation claim is false
Request certified copy of challlan and evidence
Check if meter/radar was calibrated (equipment validity important)
File appeal with traffic court within 30 days
Appear in traffic court and present defense
Get challan cancelled if officer failed to prove violation

escalation.lawyer_needed: Not required for traffic court appeal
escalation.time_limit: Appeal within 30 days of challan; hearing within 60 days

stages.action: Verify challan details and violation basis

state_variations.Maharashtra: Traffic court process streamlined; appeals processed quickly
state_variations.Delhi: Online traffic violation portal; easy appeal filing
state_variations.Karnataka: Traffic courts strict on evidence verification
state_variations.Tamil_Nadu: Equipment calibration proof mandatory for speed cameras

consequences_if_violated: Challan cancelled if officer cannot prove violation
Fine refunded if illegally issued
Compensation for harassment if challan malicious
Traffic court finding binding on police
Officer disciplinary action if repeated false challans
data.common_challan_issues: Wrong vehicle number, speed not calibrated, officer present but didn't see violation, challenged rule

data.title: Right to Access Public Services
data.right_summary: Government must provide services fairly. Delay, denial, or discrimination in public services is violation.
data.real_case: Citizen v. Government, Delhi High Court, 2023
data.case_summary: Ration card application rejected without reason for 1 year. Court ordered issue + compensation ₹50,000.

law_links.summary: Equal treatment by government; right to access public services.
law_links.full_text: State shall not discriminate in providing services to citizens.

law_links.summary: Right to information from government authorities.
law_links.full_text: Citizen can demand information from government; public interest overrides privacy.

law_links.act: Service Level Agreements and Public Service Charters
law_links.summary: Government departments set service standards.
law_links.full_text: Each department has service charter; delayed beyond timeline is violation.

user_actions: Check service delivery timeline for the service you're seeking
Apply for service with complete documentation
Get receipt/acknowledgment of application
Follow up after timeline expires without response
File complaint with department head if service delayed
File RTI request to know status of application
File complaint with ombudsman or service complaint commission
File case if government action is illegal/discriminatory

escalation.time_limit: Complaint to department within 30 days; RTI within statutory period; ombudsman within 1 year

state_variations.Delhi: Ombudsman office very active; quick resolution

consequences_if_violated: Service provided immediately without further delay
Compensation for delay and hardship
Officer responsible may face disciplinary action
Department may be directed to streamline process
Priority processing to prevent future delays
data.common_delayed_services: Ration card, PAN, Aadhar, passport, voter ID, electricity connection, water supply

data.title: Right Against Corruption
data.right_summary: You can report corruption by government officials. Whistleblowers have legal protection from retaliation.
data.case_summary: Employee reported official accepting bribes; reported to ACB. Official prosecuted; whistleblower protected.

law_links.summary: Criminal offense for government official to accept bribe.
law_links.full_text: Public servant accepting gratification for favor is criminal offense.

law_links.summary: Protection for whistleblowers reporting corruption.
law_links.full_text: Whistleblowers cannot face retaliation for reporting corruption.

law_links.summary: Transparent government; RTI for accountability.
law_links.full_text: Citizens can get information to expose corruption.

user_actions: Document corruption evidence: dates, amounts, people involved
Collect supporting evidence: receipts, videos, witness statements
Report to departmental head or ethics officer first (if safe)
File complaint with Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) or Vigilance
File complaint with ombudsman or human rights commission
Report to media if government agencies inactive
File RTI request for official's assets and income
Seek whistleblower protection order from court if threatened

escalation.time_limit: No time limit; corruption can be reported anytime

stages.action: Apply for whistleblower protection if threatened

state_variations.All_India: Prevention of Corruption Act applies uniformly

consequences_if_violated: Official prosecuted for bribery/corruption
Confiscation of ill-gotten wealth
Imprisonment up to 7 years for official
Fine recoverable from official
Whistleblower protected from retaliation
Compensation if whistleblower harassed
data.reporting_channels: ACB, Vigilance, Ombudsman, RTI, Media, Human Rights Commission, Police
data.protection_measures: Anonymous reporting allowed, legal protection from retaliation, compensation if harassed

data.title: Right to Accessibility
data.right_summary: Buildings, public transport, and services must be accessible for disabled persons. Cannot deny access due to disability.
data.real_case: Disabled Person v. Institution, Delhi High Court, 2023
data.case_summary: Bank refused entry to wheelchair user. Court ordered accessibility ramp + compensation ₹75,000.

law_links.act: Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016
law_links.summary: Right to accessibility in buildings, transport, and services.
law_links.full_text: All institutions must provide reasonable accommodation for disabled persons.

law_links.summary: Accessibility standards for buildings.
law_links.full_text: All buildings must meet accessibility requirements for disabled persons.

law_links.summary: Accessible public transport for disabled persons.
law_links.full_text: Public transport must be accessible for disabled persons.

user_actions: Identify inaccessible facility or service
Document with photos/video: missing ramp, narrow doors, no toilet access
Request reasonable accommodation: ramp, interpreter, accessible toilet
File written complaint with institution/organization
If denied, file complaint with disability officer
File complaint under Disability Act with district magistrate
File consumer complaint if service not provided
Claim compensation for denial of access

escalation.time_limit: Complaint within 1 year of denial of access

state_variations.All_India: Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act 2016 applies

consequences_if_violated: Institution forced to provide accessibility modifications
Compensation for denial of access (₹10,000-1 lakh typical)
Institution penalized by disability authority
Building can be sealed if severe accessibility violations
Regular accessibility audits may be mandated
data.accessibility_standards: Ramps (1:12 gradient), Accessible toilets, Wide doorways (0.9m min), Accessible counters, Braille signage, Staff assistance

data.title: Right to Compensation for Workplace Disability
data.right_summary: If disabled due to workplace injury/negligence, employer must provide compensation, rehabilitation, and reemployment.
data.real_case: Disabled Worker v. Employer, Gujarat High Court, 2023
data.case_summary: Worker's arm amputated in workplace accident due to negligence. Awarded ₹20 lakh + lifetime pension.

law_links.summary: Employer liable for workplace disability compensation.
law_links.full_text: Worker disabled due to workplace accident gets full compensation.

law_links.act: Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016
law_links.summary: Compensation and rehabilitation for disabled persons.
law_links.full_text: Disabled person entitled to rehabilitation services and vocational training.

law_links.summary: Amount of compensation based on disability type.
law_links.full_text: Total disability: full wages; partial: percentage of wages based on severity.

user_actions: Report workplace injury immediately to employer
Get medical examination and reports documenting disability
File workers' compensation claim with employer
Report to labor department if claim delayed/rejected
Obtain disability assessment certificate from authorized doctor
File case in labor court for compensation
Claim vocational rehabilitation and reemployment support
Claim lifetime compensation if permanent total disability

escalation.time_limit: Claim within 2 years of injury; compensation paid within 30 days

stages.action: Workplace injury report and medical examination

state_variations.Maharashtra: Liberal disability compensation; regular pension scheme
state_variations.Tamil_Nadu: Strong worker protection in disability cases

consequences_if_violated: Full compensation awarded by court
Lifetime pension if permanent total disability
Vocational rehabilitation training provided
Reemployment assistance from employer
Employer faces penalty for non-compliance
data.disability_compensation: Loss of earning capacity percentage × monthly wage × 240 months (or lifetime for permanent)
data.rehabilitation_services: Medical treatment, vocational training, job placement assistance, assistive devices
